q1: Less obvious perks of using 'live' data resources include logins and payments. How could Twitter be used in these two scenarios?
q2: Visit Programmableweb.com and search for JSON-P data sources. Why would we need JSON-P, specifically?
q3: Based on the JSON-P search results: what data resource(s) do you think might pair well with which types of Native device features?
q4: Please describe any design and functionality intentions you may have for your Demo app components this month.
q5: Briefly describe some past 'lessons learned' regarding workflow as it relates to research, design, development, etc.
r1: Using Twitter’s OAuth lets the user create an account and login with their Twitter login information. With less information having to be keyed in, this ability is useful for users on mobile devices. There is also a sense of trust with a big name such as Twitter, this would lend credibility and give the user a sense of security. For payments using a PayPal API with Twitter gives users more time saving, and trusted benefits.
r2: JSON-P is necessary in order to pull data from servers, while working around the same origin policy.
r3: My immediate thought was weather and geolocation or maps and geolocation. Another would be the camera along with Flickr or Pinterest.
r4: Am researching working with some of the different Google API’s, Google places along with geolocation for example. Something along the lines of a map showing all of the sports shops within a certain mile radius.
r5: The biggest lesson learned for me, is time management, and is something that I still struggle with a bit. There just never seem to be enough hours in the day. Have started mapping out ideas on paper, and have found that this gives me a bit more direction in my research.
